'''Emanuel Lasker''' (December 24, 1868 – January 11, 1941) was a German [[chess]] player, [[mathematician]], and [[Philosophy|philosopher]] who was [[World Chess Championship|World Chess Champion]] for 27 years, from 1894 to 1921, the longest reign of any officially recognised World Chess Champion in history. In his prime, Lasker was one of the most dominant champions, and he is still generally regarded as one of the [[Comparison of top chess players throughout history|strongest players ever]].

His contemporaries used to say that Lasker used a "psychological" approach to the game, and even that he sometimes deliberately played inferior moves to confuse opponents. Recent analysis, however, indicates that he was ahead of his time and used a more flexible approach than his contemporaries, which mystified many of them. Lasker knew contemporary analyses of openings well but disagreed with many of them. He published chess magazines and five chess books, but later players and commentators found it difficult to draw lessons from his methods.

Lasker made contributions to the development of other games. He was a first-class [[contract bridge]] player<ref name="Laskeratbridge">A detailed examination of Emanuel Lasker’s involvement in bridge is provided by the chapter ''Nicht nur Schach Emanuel Lasker als Bridgespieler'' by Robert van de Velde on pages 332-363 of ''Emanuel Lasker Denker Weltenbürger Schachweltmeister'' edited by Richard Forster, Stefan Hansen and Michael Negele (Berlin, 2009).</ref> and wrote about bridge, [[Go (game)|Go]], and his own invention, [[Lasca]]. His books about games presented a problem that is still considered notable in the [[Mathematical game|mathematical analysis of card games]]. Lasker was also a research mathematician who was known for his contributions to [[commutative algebra]], which included proving the [[Lasker–Noether theorem|primary decomposition]] of the [[ideal of a ring|ideal]]s of [[polynomial ring]]s. His philosophical works and a [[drama]] that he co-wrote, however, received little attention.

== Life and career ==

=== Early years 1868–1894 ===
[[Image:Lasker.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Lasker as a young man]]
Emanuel Lasker was born on December 24, 1868 at [[Berlinchen]] in [[Neumark]] (now [[Barlinek]] in [[Poland]]), the son of a [[Hazzan|Jewish cantor]]. At the age of eleven he was sent to Berlin to study mathematics, where he lived with his brother [[Berthold Lasker|Berthold]], eight years his senior, who taught him how to play chess. Berthold was among the world's top ten players in the early 1890s.<ref name="chessmetricsProfileBertholdLasker">{{cite web
 | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=199510SSSSS3S073074000000111000000000017510100
 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Berthold Lasker
 | publisher=Chessmetrics
 | author=[[Jeff Sonas]]
 | accessdate=2008-05-30
}}</ref> To supplement their income Emanuel Lasker played chess and card games for small stakes, especially at the Café Kaiserhof.<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography">{{cite book
 | title=UXL Encyclopedia of World Biography
 | editor=Tyle, L.B.
 | publisher=U·X·L
 | year=2002
 | isbn=0-7876-6465-0
 | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_gx5229/is_2003/ai_n19151908
 | accessdate=2008-05-30
}}</ref><ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/>

Lasker shot up through the chess rankings in 1889, when he won the Café Kaiserhof's annual Winter tournament 1888/89 and the ''Hauptturnier A'' ("second division" tournament) at the sixth [[DSB Congress|DSB Congress]] (German Chess Federation's congress) held in [[Breslau]]. Winning the Hauptturnier earned Lasker the title of "master".  The candidates were divided into two groups of ten. The top four in each group competed in a final. Lasker won his section, with 2½ points more than his nearest rival. However, scores were reset to 0 for the final. With two rounds to go, Lasker trailed the leader, Viennese amateur von Feierfeil, by 1½ points. Lasker won both of his final games, while von Feierfeil lost in the penultimate round (being mated in 121 moves after the position was reconstructed incorrectly following an adjournment) and drew in the last round. The two players were now tied. Lasker won a playoff and garnered the master title. This enabled him to play in master-level tournaments and thus launched his chess career.<ref>"The Start of a Chess Career", from ''Lasker & His Contemporaries'', issue 1, published by Thinkers Press, Inc.</ref>

Lasker finished second in an international tournament at [[Amsterdam]], ahead of some well-known masters, including [[Isidore Gunsberg]] (assessed as the second strongest player in the world at that time by Chessmetrics).<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/><ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=199510SSSSS3S048852000000111000000000011010100
 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Isidor Gunsberg
 | publisher=Chessmetrics
 | author=[[Jeff Sonas]]
}}</ref><ref name="storiascacchiTornei1880Al1899"/><ref name="Thulin1899WorldChampionshipMatchOrNot">{{cite web|url=http://www.anders.thulin.name/SUBJECTS/CHESS/SteinitzChigorin1889.pdf |title=Steinitz—Chigorin, Havana 1899 - A World Championship Match or Not? |date=August 2007 |format=PDF |author=Thulin, A. |accessdate=2008-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530021654/http://www.anders.thulin.name/SUBJECTS/CHESS/SteinitzChigorin1889.pdf |archivedate=2008-05-30 |df= }}</ref><ref name="storiascacchiMatches1880Al1999"/> In 1890 he finished third in [[Graz]], then shared first prize with his brother Berthold in a tournament in Berlin.<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1880Al1899"/><ref>{{cite book
 | author=Di Felice, Gino
 | title=Chess Results, 1747-1900
 | publisher=McFarland & Company
 | year=2004
 | pages=121–123
 | isbn=0-7864-2041-3
}}</ref> In spring 1892, he won two tournaments in London, the second and stronger of these without losing a game.<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Di Felice, Gino
 | title=Chess Results, 1747-1900
 | publisher=McFarland & Company
 | year=2004
 | pages=133–134
 | isbn=0-7864-2041-3
}}</ref><ref name="Gillam2008London1892Belfast1892"/> At [[New York City]] 1893, he won all thirteen games,<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1880Al1899"/><ref>{{cite book
 | author=Di Felice, Gino
 | title=Chess Results, 1747-1900
 | publisher=McFarland & Company
 | year=2004

}}</ref><ref name="NYTimes1894PreSteinitzLasker"/> one of the few times in chess history that a player has achieved a [[List of world records in chess#Perfect tournament and match scores|perfect score]] in a significant tournament.<ref>{{cite book

}}</ref><ref>{{cite book

[[Image:New York 1893 chess tournament.gif|thumb|right|300px|The players and tournament officials at the New York 1893 tournament]]

=== Chess competition 1894–1918 ===

==== Matches against Steinitz ====
[[Image:Wilhelm Steinitz2.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Wilhelm Steinitz]], whom Lasker beat in World Championship matches in 1894 and 1896]]
Rebuffed by Tarrasch, Lasker challenged the reigning World Champion [[Wilhelm Steinitz]] to a match for the title.<ref name="Hannakp.31"/> Initially Lasker wanted to play for US $5,000 a side and a match was agreed at stakes of $3,000 a side, but Steinitz agreed to a series of reductions when Lasker found it difficult to raise the money. The final figure was $2,000, which was less than for some of Steinitz' earlier matches (the final combined stake of $4,000 would be worth over $495,000 at 2006 values<ref>Using incomes for the adjustment factor, as the outcome depended on a few months' hard work by the players; if prices are used for the conversion, the result is over $99,000—see {{cite web
 | url=http://www.measuringworth.com/uscompare/
 | title=Six Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a U.S. Dollar Amount, 1774 to Present
 | publisher=MeasuringWorth
 | accessdate=2008-05-30
}} However, Lasker later published an analysis showing that the winning player got $1,600 and the losing player $600 out of the $4,000, as the backers who had bet on the winner got the rest: {{cite journal
 | journal=[[Lasker's Chess Magazine]]
 | volume=1
 | title=From the Editorial Chair
 |date=January 1905
 | url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Lasker%27s_Chess_Magazine/Volume_1
 | accessdate=2008-05-31
}}</ref>). Although this was publicly praised as an act of sportsmanship on Steinitz' part,<ref name="NYTimes1894PreSteinitzLasker">{{cite journal
 | journal=New York Times
 | date=11 March 1894
 | title=Ready for a big chess match
 | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1894/03/11/106900358.pdf
 | accessdate=2008-05-30
| format=PDF
}} Note: this article implies that the combined stake was $4,500, but Lasker wrote that it was $4,000: {{cite journal
 | journal=[[Lasker's Chess Magazine]]
 | volume=1
 |date=January 1905
 | url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Lasker%27s_Chess_Magazine/Volume_1
 | title=From the Editorial Chair
 | accessdate=2008-05-31
}}</ref> Steinitz may have desperately needed the money.<ref name="chessvilleSteinitzPapers">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessville.com/reviews/SteinitzPapers.htm
 | title=The Steinitz Papers - review
 | publisher=ChessVille
 | accessdate=2008-05-30
}}</ref> The match was played in 1894, at venues in New York, [[Philadelphia]], and [[Montreal]]. Steinitz had previously declared he would win without doubt, so it came as a shock when Lasker won the first game. Steinitz won the second game, and maintained the balance through the sixth. However, Lasker won all the games from the seventh to the eleventh, and Steinitz asked for a week's rest. When the match resumed, Steinitz looked in better shape and won the 13th and 14th games. Lasker struck back in the 15th and 16th, and Steinitz did not compensate for his losses in the middle of the match. Hence Lasker [[World Chess Championship 1894|won convincingly]] with ten wins, five losses and four [[draw (chess)|draws]].<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Kažić, B. M.
 | title=International Championship Chess: A Complete Record of FIDE Events
 | publisher=Pitman
 | year=1974
 | page=212
 | isbn=0-273-07078-9
}}</ref><ref name="Giffard394">{{cite book
 | author=Giffard, Nicolas
 | year=1993
 | title=Le Guide des Échecs
 | language=French
 | publisher=[[Éditions Robert Laffont]]
 | page=394
}}</ref><ref name="chessvilleSteinitzLasker1894">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessville.com/instruction/Lasker_v_Steinitz/instr_annogames_laskervsteinitz1894.htm
 | title=Lasker v. Steinitz - World Championship Match 1894
 | publisher=ChessVille
 | accessdate=2008-05-30
}}</ref> Lasker thus became the second formally recognized [[World Chess Champion]], and confirmed his title by beating Steinitz even more convincingly in their re-match in 1896–97 (ten wins, two losses, and five draws).<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1880Al1999"/><ref>{{cite book
 | author=Kažić, B. M.
 | title=International Championship Chess: A Complete Record of FIDE Events
 | publisher=Pitman
 | year=1974
 | page=213
 | isbn=0-273-07078-9
}}</ref>

==== Tournament successes ====
[[File:ELasker.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Sketch of Lasker, c. 1894]]
Influential players and journalists belittled the 1894 match both before and after it took place. Lasker's difficulty in getting backing may have been caused by hostile pre-match comments from Gunsberg and [[Leopold Hoffer]],<ref name="NYTimes1894PreSteinitzLasker"/> who had long been a bitter enemy of Steinitz.<ref name="WinterKKSCotch">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/scotch.html
 | title=Kasparov, Karpov and the Scotch
 | author=Winter, E.
 | publisher=ChessHistory
 | accessdate=2008-05-30
}}</ref> One of the complaints was that Lasker had never played the other two members of the top four, [[Siegbert Tarrasch]] and [[Mikhail Chigorin]]<ref name="NYTimes1894PreSteinitzLasker"/> – although Tarrasch had rejected a challenge from Lasker in 1892, publicly telling him to go and win an international tournament first.<ref name="LondonChessFortnightly"/><ref>{{cite web
 |url         = http://www.chess-poster.com/great_players/lasker.htm
 |title       = Emanuel Lasker
 |accessdate  = 2008-06-05
 |publisher   = Chess-Poster
 |deadurl     = yes

 |archivedate = 2008-05-27
 |df          = 
}}</ref> After the match, some commentators, notably Tarrasch, said Lasker had won mainly because Steinitz was old (58 in 1894).<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/><ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chesscorner.com/worldchamps/lasker/lasker.htm
 | title=Chess World Champions – Emanuel Lasker
 | accessdate=2008-11-21

}}</ref>

Emanuel Lasker answered these criticisms by creating an even more impressive playing record. Before [[World War I]] broke out, his most serious "setbacks" were third place at [[Hastings 1895 chess tournament|Hastings 1895]] (where he may have been suffering from the after-effects of [[typhoid fever]]<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/>), a tie for second at [[1904 Cambridge Springs International Chess Congress|Cambridge Springs 1904]], and a tie for first at the [[Chigorin Memorial]] in [[St Petersburg]] 1909.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker">{{cite book

 | year=1952
 | publisher=Andre Deutsch (now as paperback from Dover)
 | isbn=0-679-13046-2
 | authorlink=Reuben Fine
}}</ref> He won first prizes at very strong tournaments in St Petersburg (1895–96, ''Quadrangular''), [[Nuremberg 1896 chess tournament|Nuremberg (1896)]], [[London 1899 chess tournament|London (1899)]], [[Paris 1900 chess tournament|Paris (1900)]] and [[St. Petersburg 1914 chess tournament|St Petersburg (1914)]], where he overcame a 1½-point deficit to finish ahead of the rising stars, Capablanca and [[Alexander Alekhine]], who later became the next two World Champions.<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1880Al1899"/><ref name="chessmetricsCareerDetailsEmanuelLasker"/><ref name="storiascacchiTornei1900Al1909"/><ref name="storiascacchiTornei1910Al1919"/><ref>For good measure he also took first prize in a weaker tournament at Trenton Falls in 1906.</ref> For decades chess writers have reported that [[Tsar]] [[Nicholas II of Russia]] conferred the title of "[[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster of Chess]]" upon each of the five finalists at St Petersburg 1914 (Lasker, Capablanca, Alekhine, Tarrasch and [[Frank Marshall (chess player)|Marshall]]), but chess historian [[Edward Winter (chess historian)|Edward Winter]] has questioned this, stating that the earliest known sources supporting this story were published in 1940 and 1942.<ref name="KCAK">{{Cite book

==== Matches against Marshall and Tarrasch ====
{{main|World Chess Championship 1907|World Chess Championship 1908}}
Lasker's match record was as impressive between his 1896–97 re-match with Steinitz and 1914: he won all but one of his normal matches, and three of those were convincing defenses of his title. He first faced Marshall in the [[World Chess Championship 1907]], when despite his aggressive style, Marshall could not win a single game, losing eight and drawing seven (final score: 11½−3½).<ref name="Giffard396">Giffard, p.396</ref>

He then played Tarrasch in the [[World Chess Championship 1908]], first at [[Düsseldorf]] then at [[Munich]]. Tarrasch firmly believed the game of chess was governed by a precise set of principles.<ref name="Giffard396"/> For him the strength of a chess move was in its logic, not in its efficiency. Because of his stubborn principles he considered Lasker as a {{chessgloss|coffeehouse|coffeehouse player}} who won his games only thanks to dubious tricks, while Lasker mocked the arrogance of Tarrasch who, in his opinion, shone more in [[Salon (gathering)|salons]] than at the chessboard. At the opening ceremony, Tarrasch refused to talk to Lasker, only saying: "Mr. Lasker, I have only three words to say to you: check and mate!"<ref>{{cite web

Lasker gave a brilliant answer on the chessboard, winning four of the first five games, and playing a type of chess Tarrasch could not understand. For example, in the second game after 19 moves arose a situation (see diagram) in which Lasker was a [[pawn (chess)|pawn]] down, with a {{chessgloss|bad bishop}} and {{chessgloss|doubled pawns}}. At this point it appeared Tarrasch was winning, but 20 moves later he was forced to [[resign (chess)|resign]].<ref name="Giffard398">Giffard, p.398</ref> Lasker eventually won by 10½−5½ (eight wins, five draws, and three losses). ==== Matches against Janowski ====
{{main|World Chess Championship 1910 (Lasker–Janowski)}}

In 1909 Lasker drew a short match (two wins, two losses) against [[Dawid Janowski]], an all-out attacking [[Polish people|Polish]] expatriate. Several months later they played a longer match in Paris, and chess historians still debate whether this was for the World Chess Championship.<ref>Several authors have considered this match as a World Chess Championship, for instance:

*{{cite book

 | page=6
 | year=1986
 | isbn=0-02-028700-3

 | author=Giffard, Nicolas
 | language=French

More recent sources consider it was only an exhibition match:
*{{cite web

 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/winter38.html#5199._Lasker_v_Janowsky_Paris_1909
 | title=Chess Notes 5199
 | publisher=ChessHistory.com
 | authorlink=Edward Winter (chess historian)}}

Lasker crushed his opponent, winning 9½−1½ (eight wins, three draws, no losses).<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1900Al1914"/> Janowski did not understand Lasker's moves, and after his first three losses he declared to [[Edward Lasker]], "Your [[homonym]] plays so stupidly that I cannot even look at the chessboard when he thinks. I am afraid I will not do anything good in this match."<ref name="Giffard400"/>

==== Match against Schlechter ====
{{main|World Chess Championship 1910 (Lasker–Schlechter)}}
[[Image:Carl Schlechter (profile).png|thumb|upright|Schlechter would have taken Lasker's world title if he had won or drawn the last game of their 1910 match.]]
Between his two matches against Janowski, Lasker arranged another [[World Chess Championship 1910 (Lasker–Schlechter)|World Chess Championship]] in January–February 1910 against [[Carl Schlechter]]. Schlechter was a modest gentleman, who was generally unlikely to win the major chess tournaments by his peaceful inclination, his lack of aggressiveness and his willingness to accept most [[draw (chess)|draw]] [[draw by agreement|offers]] from his opponents (about 80% of his games finished by a draw).<ref name="Giffard404">Giffard 1993, p. 404</ref>  According to Isaak and Vladimir Linder, the match was originally to be a 30 game affair and Schlechter would have to win by a two game margin. They note that the Austrian chess historian Micheal Ehn has established, based on the Viennese sources, that Lasker agreed to forgo the plus two provision in view of the match being subsequently reduced to only 10 games. For proof Ehn quoted Schlechter's comment printed in Allgemeine Sportzeitung (ASZ) of December 9, 1909 "There will be ten games in all. The winner on points will receive the title of world champion. If the points are equal, the decision will be made by the arbiter."
<ref>
{{cite book
| title=Emanuel Lasker, 2nd World Chess Champion
| author=Isaak and Vladimir Linder
| publisher=Russel Enterprises Inc.
| date=2010
| page=109 }}
</ref>

At the beginning, Lasker tried to attack but Schlechter had no difficulty defending, so that the first four games finished in draws. In the fifth game Lasker had a big advantage, but committed a blunder that cost him the game. Hence at the middle of the match Schlechter was one point ahead. The next four games were drawn, despite fierce play from both players. In the sixth Schlechter managed to draw a game being a pawn down. In the seventh Lasker nearly lost because of a beautiful [[The exchange (chess)#The exchange sacrifice|exchange sacrifice]] from Schlechter. In the ninth only a blunder from Lasker allowed Schlechter to draw a lost [[chess endgame|ending]]. The score before the last game was thus 5–4 for Schlechter. In the tenth game Schlechter tried to win tactically and took a big advantage, but he missed a clear win at the 35th move, continued to take increasing risks and finished by losing.<ref name="Giffard406">Giffard 1993, p. 406</ref> Hence the match was a draw and Lasker remained World Champion.

==== Abandoned challenges ====
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Capablanca3.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[José Raúl Capablanca]] won the world title from Lasker in 1921]] -->
In 1911 Lasker received a challenge for a world title match against the rising star [[José Raúl Capablanca]]. Lasker was unwilling to play the traditional "first to win ten games" type of match in the semi-tropical conditions of [[Havana]], especially as drawn games were becoming more frequent and the match might last for over six months. He therefore made a counter-proposal: if neither player had a lead of at least two games by the end of the match, it should be considered a draw; the match should be limited to the best of thirty games, counting draws; except that if either player won six games ''and'' led by at least two games before thirty games were completed, he should be declared the winner; the champion should decide the venue and stakes, and should have the exclusive right to publish the games; the challenger should deposit a forfeit of US $2,000 (equivalent to over $194,000 in 2006 values<ref>Using average incomes as the conversion factor; if prices are used for the conversion, the result is about $45,000—see {{cite web
 | url=http://www.measuringworth.com/uscompare/
 | title=Six Ways to Compute the Relative Value of a U.S. Dollar Amount, 1774 to Present
 | publisher=MeasuringWorth
 | accessdate=2008-06-05
}}</ref>); the time limit should be twelve moves per hour; play should be limited to two sessions of 2½ hours each per day, five days a week. Capablanca objected to the time limit, the short playing times, the thirty-game limit, and especially the requirement that he must win by two games to claim the title, which he regarded as unfair. Lasker took offence at the terms in which Capablanca criticized the two-game lead condition and broke off negotiations, and until 1914 Lasker and Capablanca were not on speaking terms. However, at the 1914 St. Petersburg tournament, Capablanca proposed a set of rules for the conduct of World Championship matches, which were accepted by all the leading players, including Lasker.<ref name="graemecree1921WorldChessChampionship">{{Cite web
 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050120165616/http://members.aol.com/graemecree/chesschamps/world/world1921.htm
 | title=1921 World Chess Championship
 | accessdate=2008-11-21
 | archivedate=January 20, 2005
 | url=http://members.aol.com/graemecree/chesschamps/world/world1921.htm
}} This cites: a report of Lasker's concerns about the location and duration of the match, in the ''New York Evening Post'', March 15, 1911; Capablanca's letter of December 20, 1911 to Lasker, stating his objections to Lasker's proposal; Lasker's letter to Capablanca, breaking off negotiations; Lasker's letter of April 27, 1921 to Alberto Ponce of the Havana Chess Club, proposing to resign the 1921 match; and Ponce's reply, accepting the resignation.</ref>

Late in 1912 Lasker entered into negotiations for a world title match with [[Akiba Rubinstein]], whose tournament record for the previous few years had been on a par with Lasker's and a little ahead of Capablanca's.<ref name="chessmetricsProfileRubinstein">{{cite web
 | url=http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/PlayerProfile.asp?Params=188510SSSSS3S112008189006131000000000026310100
 | title=Chessmetrics Player Profile: Akiba Rubinstein
 | publisher=Chessmetrics
 | author=[[Jeff Sonas]]
 | accessdate=2008-06-04
}}</ref> The two players agreed to play a match if Rubinstein could raise the funds, but Rubinstein had few rich friends to back him and the match was never played. This situation demonstrated some of the flaws inherent in the championship system then being used. The start of World War I in summer 1914 put an end to hopes that Lasker would play either Rubinstein or Capablanca for the World Championship in the near future.<ref name="Horowitz1973MorphyToFischer">{{cite book
 | title=From Morphy to Fischer
 | author=Horowitz, I.A.
 | publisher=Batsford
 | year=1973
 | authorlink=Israel Horowitz
}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
 | title=Classical Chess Matches, 1907–1913
 | author=Wilson, F.
 | year=1975
 | publisher=Dover
 | isbn=0-486-23145-3
}}</ref>
Throughout World War I (1914–1918) Lasker played in only two serious chess events. He convincingly won (5½−½) a non-title match against Tarrasch in 1916.<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1915Al1929"/> In September–October 1918, shortly before the [[Armistice with Germany (Compiègne)|armistice]], he won a quadrangular (four-player) tournament, half a point ahead of Rubinstein.<ref>{{cite web

Lasker gained his [[abitur]] (high school graduation certificate) at [[Landsberg an der Warthe]], now a [[Poland|Polish]] town named Gorzów Wielkopolski but then part of [[Prussia]]. === Match against Capablanca ===
{{main|World Chess Championship 1921|}}
In January 1920 Lasker and [[José Raúl Capablanca]] signed an agreement to play a World Championship match in 1921, noting that Capablanca was not free to play in 1920. Because of the delay, Lasker insisted on a final clause that allowed him to play anyone else for the championship in 1920, that nullified the contract with Capablanca if Lasker lost a title match in 1920, and that stipulated that if Lasker resigned the title Capablanca should become World Champion. Lasker had previously included in his agreement before World War I to play [[Akiba Rubinstein]] for the title a similar clause that if he resigned the title, it should become Rubinstein's.<ref name="WinterHowCapaBecameChampion"/>

A report in the ''American Chess Bulletin'' (July–August 1920 issue) said that Lasker had resigned the world title in favor of Capablanca because the conditions of the match were unpopular in the chess world. The ''American Chess Bulletin'' speculated that the conditions were not sufficiently unpopular to warrant resignation of the title, and that Lasker's real concern was that there was not enough financial backing to justify his devoting nine months to the match.<ref name="WinterHowCapaBecameChampion">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/capablanca2.html
 | title=How Capablanca Became World Champion
 | author=Winter, Edward
 | publisher=ChessHistory
 | accessdate=2008-06-05
 | authorlink=Edward Winter (chess historian)
}} Winter cites: ''American Chess Bulletin'' (July–August 1920 issue) for Lasker's resignation of the title, the ''ACB''{{'s}} theory about Lasker's real motive and Havana's offer of $20,000; [[Amos Burn]] in ''The Field'' of 3 July 1920, the ''British Chess Magazine'' of August 1920 and other sources for protestations that Lasker had no right to nominate a successor; [[Amos Burn]] in ''The Field'' of 3 July 1920 and E.S. Tinsley in ''The Times'' (London) of 26 June 1920 for criticism of the conditions Lasker set for the defense of the title; ''American Chess Bulletin'' September–October 1920 for Lasker's and Capablanca's statements that Capablanca was the champion and Lasker the challenger, for Capablanca's statement that Lasker's contract with Rubinstein had contained a clause allowing him to abdicate in favor of Rubinstein, for Lasker's intention to resign the title if he beat Capablanca and his support for an international organization, preferably based in the Americas, to manage international chess. Winter says that before Lasker's abdication some chess correspondents had been calling for Lasker to be stripped of the title. For a very detailed account given by Capablanca after the match, see {{Cite journal
 | journal=British Chess Magazine
 | author=Capablanca, José Raúl
 | date=October 1922
 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/capablancalasker.html
 | title=Capablanca's Reply to Lasker (presented by Edward Winter)
 | accessdate=2008-06-05
 | authorlink=José Raúl Capablanca
}}</ref> When Lasker resigned the title in favor of Capablanca he was unaware that enthusiasts in [[Havana]] had just raised $20,000 to fund the match provided it was played there. When Capablanca learned of Lasker's resignation he went to the Netherlands, where Lasker was living at the time, to inform him that Havana would finance the match. In August 1920 Lasker agreed to play in Havana, but insisted that he was the challenger as Capablanca was now the champion. Capablanca signed an agreement that accepted this point, and soon afterwards published a letter confirming this. Lasker also stated that, if he beat Capablanca, he would resign the title so that younger masters could compete for it.<ref name="WinterHowCapaBecameChampion"/>

The match was played in March–April 1921. After four draws, the fifth game saw Lasker [[blunder (chess)|blunder]] with Black in an equal [[chess endgame|ending]]. Capablanca's solid style allowed him to easily draw the next four games, without taking any risks. In the tenth game, Lasker as White played a position with an [[Isolated Queen Pawn|isolated queen pawn]] but failed to create the necessary activity and Capablanca reached a superior ending, which he duly won. The eleventh and fourteenth games were also won by Capablanca, and Lasker resigned the match.<ref>{{cite book
 | title=Le guide des échecs
 | author=Giffard, Nicolas
 | language=French
 | year=1993
 | publisher=[[Éditions Robert Laffont]]
 | page=412
}}</ref>

[[Reuben Fine]] and [[Harry Golombek]] attributed this to Lasker's being in mysteriously poor form.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/><ref>{{cite book
 | author=Golombek, H.
 | chapter=On the Way to the World Championship |page=59
 | title=Capablanca's Hundred Best Games of Chess
 | editor=Golombek, H.
 | publisher=G. Bell & Sons
 | year=1959
 | isbn=0-679-14044-1
}}</ref> On the other hand, [[Vladimir Kramnik]] thought that Lasker played quite well and the match was an "even and fascinating fight" until Lasker blundered in the last game, and explained that Capablanca was 20 years younger, a slightly stronger player, and had more recent competitive practice.<ref name="KramnikSteinitzToKasparov"/>

=== European life and travels ===
Lasker was in his early 50s when he lost the world championship to Capablanca, and he retired from serious match play afterwards;<ref name="storiascacchiMatches1915Al1929"/><ref name="storiascacchiMatches1930Al1949">{{cite web

 | title=I matches 1930/49
 | publisher=La grande storia degli scacchi
 | accessdate=2009-09-03
}}</ref> his only other match was a short exhibition against [[Frank James Marshall]] in 1940, which Lasker lost. After winning the [[Moravská Ostrava 1923 chess tournament]] (without a single loss), the [[New York 1924 chess tournament]] (1½ points ahead of Capablanca) and finishing second at Moscow in 1925 (1½ points behind [[Efim Bogoljubow]], ½ point ahead of Capablanca),<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1920Al1929"/> he effectively retired from serious chess.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/>

Emanuel Lasker was so distracted by this news that he lost badly to [[Carlos Torre]] the same day.<ref>{{cite web

 | page=218
 | isbn=0-19-866164-9
}}</ref> After a short stay in England, in 1935 they were invited to live in the USSR by [[Nikolai Krylenko]], the Commissar of Justice who was responsible for the [[Show trial|Moscow show trials]] and, in his other capacity as Sports Minister, was an enthusiastic supporter of chess.<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/> In the USSR, Lasker renounced his German citizenship and received Soviet citizenship.<ref>{{cite book
 |author1=Litmanowicz, Władysław  |author2=Giżycki, Jerzy
 | title=Szachy od A do Z
 | publisher=Wydawnictwo ''Sport i Turystyka'' Warszawa
 | year=1986
 | isbn=83-217-2481-7 
 | id=(1. A-M),  {{isbn|83-217-2745-X}} (2. N-Z)
}}</ref> He took permanent residence in Moscow, and was given a post at Moscow's Institute for Mathematics<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/> and a post of trainer of the USSR national team.<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Weinstein, Boris Samoilovich
 | title='''Myslitel''' (''Thinker'')
 | publisher=Fizkultura i sport
 | year=1981
 | pages=104 (Russian edition)
 | accessdate=2009-02-18
}}</ref>
Lasker returned to competitive chess to make some money, finishing fifth in [[Zürich 1934 chess tournament|Zürich 1934]] and third in [[Moscow 1935 chess tournament|Moscow 1935]] (undefeated, ½ point behind [[Mikhail Botvinnik]] and [[Salo Flohr]]; ahead of Capablanca, [[Rudolf Spielmann]] and several Soviet masters), sixth in Moscow 1936 and seventh equal in [[Nottingham]] 1936.<ref name="storiascacchiTornei1930Al1939"/> His performance in Moscow 1935 at age 66 was hailed as "a biological miracle".<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Reuben Fine
 | title=The World's Great Chess Games
 | publisher=Dover
 | year=1976
 | page=51
 | isbn=0-486-24512-8
}}</ref>

[[Joseph Stalin]]'s [[Great Purge]] started at about the same time the Laskers arrived in the USSR.

===Return to the United States and death===
In August 1937, Martha and Emanuel Lasker decided to leave the Soviet Union, and they moved, via the Netherlands, to the United States (first Chicago, next New York) in October 1937.<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Weinstein, Boris Samoilovich
 | title='''Myslitel''' (''Thinker'')
 | publisher=Fizkultura i sport
 | year=1981
 | pages=105 (Russian edition)
 | accessdate=2009-02-18
}}</ref> The next year Emanuel Lasker's patron, Krylenko, was removed from his office and executed. Meanwhile, in the United States Lasker tried to support himself by giving chess and bridge lectures and exhibitions, as he was now too old for serious competition.<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/><ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/> In 1940 he published his last book, ''The Community of the Future'', in which he proposed solutions for serious political problems, including [[anti-Semitism]] and unemployment.<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/>

Lasker died of a [[kidney]] infection in New York on January 11, 1941, at the age of 72, as a charity patient at the [[Mount Sinai Hospital, New York|Mount Sinai Hospital]].<ref name="BillWallEmLasker"/> He was buried at historic Beth Olom Cemetery, Queens, New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/631|title=Dr Emanuel Lasker (1868–1941) – Find A Grave...|website=Findagrave.com|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> His wife Martha and his sister, Mrs. Lotta Hirschberg, survived him.<ref>{{cite web
 | title=5076. Lasker's last words
 | author=Winter, Edward
 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/winter36.html#5076._Laskers_last_words_C.N._4705
 | publisher=ChessHistory
 | accessdate=2008-12-28
}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
 | author=Landsberger, K.
 | title=The Steinitz Papers: Letters and Documents of the First World Chess Champion
 | publisher=McFarland
 | year=2002
 | isbn= 0-7864-1193-7
 | page=295
 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=NltT4BinugsC&pg=PA295&dq=lasker+capablanca+1921
 | accessdate=2008-12-28
}}</ref>

== Assessment ==

=== Playing strength and style ===
Lasker was considered to have a "psychological" method of play in which he considered the subjective qualities of his opponent, in addition to the objective requirements of his position on the board. [[Richard Réti]] published a lengthy analysis of Lasker's play in which he concluded that Lasker deliberately played inferior moves that he knew would make his opponent uncomfortable.<ref>Réti wrote, "In analyzing Lasker's tournament games, I was struck by his lasting and at first seemingly incredible good luck. ... There is no denying the fact that over and over again Lasker's exposition is poor, that he is in a losing position hundreds of times and, nevertheless, wins in the end."{{cite book
 | author=Réti, Richard
 | title=Masters of the Chessboard
 | publisher=Dover Publications
 | year=1976
 | page=132
 | isbn=0-486-23384-7
}} Réti considered, but rejected as too improbable, the "hypothesis of lasting luck", finally concluding that the only explanation for Lasker's repeated success from bad positions is that he "often plays badly on purpose". ''Id.'' Réti concluded that Lasker studied his opponents' strong and weak points, and that, "He is not so much interested in making the objectively best moves as he is in making those most disagreeable to his opponent; he turns the game in a direction not suitable to the style of his opponent and on this unaccustomed road leads him to the abyss, often by means of intentionally bad moves, as I have previously described." ''Id.'' at 133.</ref> [[William Pollock (chess player)|W. H. K. Pollock]] commented, "It is no easy matter to reply correctly to Lasker's bad moves."<ref>{{cite book
 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=9SECAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22Pollock+Memories%22&printsec=frontcover
 | author=Rowland, Mrs. F.F.
 | title=Pollock Memories: A Collection of Chess Games, Problems, &c., &c.
 | publisher=Chess Player's Chronicle
 | year=1899
 | page=78
 | isbn=978-1-4371-9392-3
}}</ref>

Lasker himself denied the claim that he deliberately played bad moves, and most modern writers agree. According to [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] [[Andrew Soltis]] and [[International Master]] [[John L. Watson]], the features that made his play mysterious to contemporaries now appear regularly in modern play: the g2–g4 "Spike" attack against the [[Sicilian Defence, Dragon Variation|Dragon Sicilian]];{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} [[Sacrifice (chess)|sacrifices]] to gain positional advantage; playing the "practical" move rather than trying to find the best move; counterattacking and complicating the game before a disadvantage became serious.<ref name="SoltisLaskerMatters">{{cite book
 | title=Why Lasker Matters
 | author=Soltis, A.
 | publisher=Batsford
 | year=2005
 | page=5
 | isbn=0-7134-8983-9
 | url=http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/jwatsonbkrev80.html
}} The URL is a review by [[John L. Watson]]. Another review, with examples, is at {{cite web
 | url=http://www.chesscafe.com/text/review538.pdf
 | accessdate=2009-01-01
 | title=Analyzing an Enigma
 | publisher=ChessCafe
 | author=Taylor Kingston
}}</ref><ref>"Lasker's greatest skill in defense was his ability to render a normal (inferior) position chaotic": {{cite book
 | author=Crouch, C.
 | title=How to Defend in Chess
 | publisher=Everyman
 | year=2000
 | isbn=1-85744-250-4
}}; review including this quotation at {{cite web
 | title=How to Defend in Chess: review
 | author=Watson, J.
 | url=http://www.jeremysilman.com/book_reviews_jw/jw_ht_defend_chess.html
 | publisher=JeremySilman
 | accessdate=2008-11-19
}}</ref> Former World Champion [[Vladimir Kramnik]] said, "He realized that different types of advantage could be interchangeable: tactical edge could be converted into strategic advantage and vice versa", which mystified contemporaries who were just becoming used to the theories of Steinitz as codified by [[Siegbert Tarrasch]].<ref name="KramnikSteinitzToKasparov"/>

[[Max Euwe]] opined that the real reason behind Lasker's success was his "exceptional defensive technique" and that "almost all there is to say about defensive chess can be demonstrated by examples from the games of Steinitz and Lasker", with the former exemplifying passive defence and the latter an active defence.<ref>{{cite book
 | author=[[Max Euwe]] and Hans Kramer
 | title=The Middlegame
 | publisher=Hays Publishing
 | year=1994
 | pages=93, 101
}}</ref>

The famous win against [[José Raúl Capablanca]] at [[St. Petersburg 1914 chess tournament|St. Petersburg in 1914]], which Lasker needed in order to retain any chance of catching up with Capablanca, is sometimes offered as evidence of his "psychological" approach. [[Reuben Fine]] describes Lasker's choice of opening, the [[Ruy Lopez, Exchange Variation|Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez]], as "innocuous but psychologically potent".<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/> However, an analysis of Lasker's use of this variation throughout his career concludes that he had excellent results with it as White against top-class opponents, and sometimes used it in "must-win" situations.<ref name="WrinnLaskerRuyExchangeVariation">As White in [[Ruy Lopez, Exchange Variation|Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez]] Lasker scored ten wins, three draws and just one loss, to Steinitz in 1894. Lasker also won the three recorded games in which he played the variation as Black; one was against [[Alexander Alekhine|Alekhine]], in the 1914 St. Petersburg Tournament, the day before Lasker beat Capablanca.{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chesscafe.com/text/skittles230.pdf
 | title=Lasker and the Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez - Part 1
 | author=Wrinn, Steve
 | accessdate=2008-06-09
 | publisher=ChessCafe
 | format=PDF
}} and {{cite web
 | url=http://www.chesscafe.com/text/skittles232.pdf
 | title=Lasker and the Exchange Variation of the Ruy Lopez – Part 2
 | author=Wrinn, Steve
 | accessdate=2008-06-09
 | publisher=ChessCafe
 | format=PDF
}}</ref> [[Luděk Pachman]] writes that Lasker's choice presented his opponent with a [[dilemma]]: with only a ½ point lead, Capablanca would have wanted to play safe; but the Exchange Variation's [[pawn structure]] gives White an [[Chess endgame|endgame]] advantage, and Black must use his {{chessgloss|bishop pair}} aggressively in the [[middlegame]] to nullify this.<ref name="Pachman1987StPetersburg1914">{{cite book|last=Pachman|first=L.|title=Decisive Games in Chess History|publisher=Courier Dover|year=1987|pages=64–68|chapter=St Petersburg 1914: Drawing Variation - The Way to Victory|isbn=0-486-25323-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jlgJTCyonAgC&pg=PA1&dq=capablanca|accessdate=2009-06-04}}</ref> In Kramnik's opinion, Lasker's play in this game demonstrated deep positional understanding, rather than psychology.<ref name="KramnikSteinitzToKasparov">{{cite web
 |url          = http://www.kramnik.com/eng/interviews/getinterview.aspx?id=61
 |accessdate   = 2009-01-02
 |title        = Kramnik Interview: From Steinitz to Kasparov
 |author       = [[Vladimir Kramnik]]
 |publisher    = Kramnik.com
 |archive-url  = https://web.archive.org/web/20080512052013/http://www.kramnik.com/eng/interviews/getinterview.aspx?id=61
 |archive-date = 2008-05-12
 |dead-url     = yes
 |df           = 
}}</ref>

Fine reckoned Lasker paid little attention to the openings,<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/> but Capablanca thought Lasker knew the openings very well but disagreed with a lot of contemporary opening analysis. In fact before the 1894 world title match, Lasker studied the openings thoroughly, especially Steinitz's favorite lines. He played primarily e4 openings, particularly the [[Ruy Lopez]]. He opened with 1.d4 relatively rarely, although his d4 games had a higher winning percentage than his e4 ones. With the Black pieces, he mainly answered 1.e4 with the [[French Defense]] and 1.d4 with the [[Queen's Gambit]]. Lasker also used the [[Sicilian Defense]] fairly often. In Capablanca's opinion, no player surpassed Lasker in the ability to assess a position quickly and accurately, in terms of who had the better prospects of winning and what strategy each side should adopt.<ref name="HavanurReviewWhyLaskerMatters">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessville.com/reviews/WhyLaskerMatters2.htm
 | title=Why Lasker Matters – review by Nagesh Havanur
 | author=Nagesh Havanur
 | publisher=ChessVille
 | accessdate=2008-11-21
}}</ref> Capablanca also wrote that Lasker was so adaptable that he played in no definite style, and that he was both a tenacious defender and a very efficient finisher of his own attacks.<ref>{{Cite news
 | author=Capablanca, José Raúl
 | title=The Ideal Style of the Masters
 | newspaper=Mundial
 | date=May 1927
 | pages=1–4
 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/capablanca3.html
 | accessdate=2009-01-02
 | authorlink=José Raúl Capablanca
}}</ref>

Lasker followed [[Wilhelm Steinitz|Steinitz]]'s principles, and both demonstrated a completely different chess paradigm than the “romantic” mentality before them. Thanks to Steinitz and Lasker, positional players gradually became common ([[Siegbert Tarrasch|Tarrasch]], [[Carl Schlechter|Schlechter]], and [[Akiba Rubinstein|Rubinstein]] stand out.) But, while Steinitz created a new school of chess thought, Lasker’s talents were far harder for the masses to grasp; hence there was no Lasker school.<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Garry Kasparov
 | title=My Great Predecessors - Part I
 | publisher=Everyman Chess
 | year=2003
 | pages=187–222
 | isbn=1857443306
}}</ref>

In addition to his enormous chess skill, Lasker was said to have an excellent competitive temperament: his rival [[Siegbert Tarrasch]] once said, "Lasker occasionally loses a game, but he never loses his head."<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/> Lasker enjoyed the need to adapt to varying styles and to the shifting fortunes of tournaments.<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/> Although very strong in matches, he was even stronger in tournaments. For over 20 years, he always finished ahead of the younger Capablanca: at St. Petersburg 1914, New York 1924, Moscow 1925, and Moscow 1935.<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Harry Golombek
 | title=Capablanca's 100 Best Games of Chess
 | publisher=David McKay
 | year=1978
 | pages=37, 88, 116, 222
 | isbn=0-679-14044-1
}}</ref> Only in 1936 (15 years after their match), when Lasker was 67, did Capablanca finish ahead of him.<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Reuben Fine
 | title=The World's Great Chess Games
 | publisher=Dover
 | year=1976
 | page=50
 | isbn=0-486-24512-8
}}</ref>

In 1964, ''Chessworld'' magazine published an article in which future World Champion [[Bobby Fischer]] listed the ten greatest players in history.<ref>Bobby Fischer, "The Ten Greatest Masters in History", ''Chessworld'', Vol. 1, No. 1 (January–February 1964), pp. 56-61.</ref> Fischer did not include Lasker in the list, deriding him as a "coffee-house player [who] knew nothing about openings and didn't understand positional chess".<ref>Fischer, "The Ten Greatest Masters in History", p. 59.</ref> In a poll of the world's leading players taken some time after Fischer's list appeared, Tal, Korchnoi, and [[Robert Byrne (chess player)|Robert Byrne]] all said that Lasker was the greatest player ever.<ref>{{cite book
 | title=Profile of a Prodigy
 | author=Brady, Frank
 | publisher=David McKay
 | year=1973
 | edition=2nd
 | page=78
 | isbn=0-486-25925-0
}}</ref> Both [[Pal Benko]] and Byrne stated that Fischer later reconsidered and said that Lasker was a great player.<ref name="Benko">{{cite book
 | title=Pal Benko: My Life, Games and Compositions
 | author1=Benko, Pal
 | author2=Silman, Jeremy
 | publisher=Siles Press
 | year=2003
 | page=429
 | isbn=1-890085-08-1
}}</ref><ref>Brady 1973, p. 79.</ref>

=== Influence on chess ===
[[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-14194, Emanuel Lasker.jpg|thumb|upright|Lasker at home in Berlin, in 1933]]
Lasker founded no school of players who played in a similar style.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker"/> [[Max Euwe]], World Champion 1935–1937 and a prolific writer of chess manuals, who had a lifetime 0–3 score against Lasker,<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chess.pl?yearcomp=exactly&year=&playercomp=either&pid=&player=Euwe&pid2=&player2=Lasker&movescomp=exactly&moves=&opening=&eco=&result=
 | title=Euwe–Lasker Results
 | author=ChessGames.com
 | accessdate=2008-12-03
}}</ref> said, "It is not possible to learn much from him. One can only stand and wonder."<ref name="JeffreysReviewWhyLaskerMatters">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessville.com/reviews/WhyLaskerMatters.htm
 | title=Why Lasker Matters - review by Michael Jeffreys
 | author= Michael Jeffreys
 | publisher=ChessVille.com
 | accessdate=2008-06-10
}}</ref> However, Lasker's pragmatic, combative approach had a great influence on [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] players like [[Mikhail Tal]] and [[Viktor Korchnoi]].<ref name="CrouchOnLasker">{{cite book
 | author=Crouch, C.
 | year=2000
 | title=How to Defend in Chess
 | publisher=Everyman Chess
 | page=115
 | isbn=1-85744-250-4
}}</ref>

There are several "Lasker Variations" in the [[chess opening]]s, including Lasker's Defense to the [[Queen's Gambit]], Lasker's Defense to the [[Evans Gambit]] (which effectively ended the use of this [[gambit]] in tournament play until a revival in the 1990s),<ref name="FineIdeasBehindOpenings">Lasker's Defense: {{cite book
 | author=[[Reuben Fine|Fine]], R.
 | title=The Ideas behind the Chess Openings
 | year=1948
 | page=63
 | publisher=Bell
 | isbn=0-8129-1756-1
}} Revival:{{cite book
 | title=Batsford's Modern Chess Openings
 | author=De Firmian, N.
 | chapter=Evans Gambit
 | page=26
 | publisher=Batsford
 | year=2000
 | isbn=0-7134-8656-2
}}</ref> and the Lasker Variation in the McCutcheon Variation of the [[French Defense]].<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessville.com/instruction/Openings/French_Defense/instr_open_french_eco.htm
 | title=French Defense
 | publisher=ChessVille.com
 | accessdate=2008-06-10
}}</ref>

One of Lasker's most famous games is [[Lasker - Bauer, Amsterdam, 1889|Lasker–Bauer, Amsterdam 1889]], in which he sacrificed both bishops in a maneuver later repeated in a number of games. Similar sacrifices had already been played by [[Cecil Valentine De Vere]] and [[John Owen (chess player)|John Owen]], but these were not in major events and Lasker probably had not seen them.<ref name="JeffreysReviewWhyLaskerMatters"/>

Lasker was shocked by the poverty in which [[Wilhelm Steinitz]] died and did not intend to die in similar circumstances.<ref>Lasker wrote "I who vanquished him must see to it that his great achievement, his theories should find justice, and I must avenge the wrongs he suffered". {{cite book
 | title=Lasker's Manual of Chess
 | author=Lasker, Emanuel
 | publisher=Dover
 | origyear=1925| year=1960
 | isbn=0-486-20640-8
 | url=http://www.mark-weeks.com/chess/z4ls$wix.htm
 | accessdate=2008-05-31
}}</ref> He became notorious for demanding high fees for playing matches and tournaments, and he argued that players should own the [[copyright]] in their games rather than let publishers get all the profits.<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/><ref name="wikisourceLaskersChessMagazineVol1">{{cite journal
 | journal=[[Lasker's Chess Magazine]]
 | volume=1
 | date=January 1905
 | url=http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Lasker%27s_Chess_Magazine/Volume_1
 | title=From the Editorial Chair
 | author=Lasker, Emanuel
 | accessdate=2008-05-31
}}</ref> These demands initially angered editors and other players, but helped to pave the way for the rise of full-time chess professionals who earn most of their living from playing, writing and teaching.<ref name="UXLEncyclopediaBiography"/> Copyright in chess games had been contentious at least as far back as the mid-1840s,<ref name="WinterChessNote4767">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/winter29.html#4767._Copyright
 | title=Chess Note 4767 Copyright
 | publisher=ChessHistory.com
 | author=Edward Winter
 | accessdate=2008-06-25
}}</ref> and Steinitz and Lasker vigorously asserted that players should own the copyright and wrote copyright clauses into their match contracts.<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/copyright.html
 | title=Copyright on Chess Games
 | publisher=ChessHistory.com
 | author=Edward Winter
 | accessdate=2008-06-25

=== Work in other fields ===
Lasker was also a mathematician. In his 1905 article on [[commutative algebra]], Lasker introduced the theory of [[Lasker–Noether theorem|primary decomposition]] of [[ideal of a ring|ideal]]s, which has influence in the theory of [[Noetherian ring]]s.<ref>He defined the [[primary decomposition]] property of the [[ring ideal|ideal]]s of some [[commutative ring]]s when he proved that [[polynomial ring]]s have the primary decomposition property.</ref> Rings having the ''primary decomposition property'' are called "[[Laskerian ring]]s" in his honor.<ref name="dcsStAndrewsLaskerBio"/><ref>{{cite book
 | title=Unknown Quantity: A Real and Imaginary History of Algebra
 | author=Derbyshire, J.
 | publisher=National Academy Press
 |date=December 2006
 | isbn=0-309-09657-X
 | chapter=12: The Lady of the Rings
 | pages=234–235
 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=5SIPdYbUhU0C&pg=PP1&dq=lasker+einstein+hannak
 | accessdate=2008-12-29
}}</ref>

His attempt to create a general theory of all competitive activities were followed by more consistent efforts from [[John von Neumann|von Neumann]] on [[game theory]],<ref name="LeonardCreationOfGameTheory">{{cite web
 | url=http://www.cesmep.unito.it/WP/2007/7_WP_Cesmep.pdf
 | title=Working Paper - New Light on von Neumann: politics, psychology and the creation of game theory
 | author=Leonard, J.
 | publisher=Department of Economics, University of Turin
 | accessdate=2008-05-01
 | format=PDF
}}</ref> and his later writings about card games presented a significant issue in the [[Mathematical game|mathematical analysis of card games]].<ref name="Wastlund2005TwoPersonSingleSuitWhist"/>

However, his dramatic and philosophical works have never been highly regarded.<ref name="laskergesellschaftLaskerNewApproaches"/>

== Friends and relatives ==
Lasker was a good friend of [[Albert Einstein]], who wrote the introduction to the posthumous biography ''Emanuel Lasker, The Life of a Chess Master'' from Dr. Jacques Hannak (1952).<ref>{{cite book
 | author=Hannak, J.
 | title=Emanuel Lasker, The Life of a Chess Master
 | year=1952
 | url=http://philosophyofscienceportal.blogspot.com/2008/05/einstein-laskers-and-chess.html
 | accessdate=2009-01-05
 | isbn=0-486-26706-7
}}</ref> In this preface Einstein express his satisfaction at having met Lasker, writing:
{{quote|Emanuel Lasker was undoubtedly one of the most interesting people I came to know in my later years. We must be thankful to those who have penned the story of his life for this and succeeding generations. For there are few men who have had a warm interest in all the great human problems and at the same time kept their personality so uniquely independent.}}

Poet [[Else Lasker-Schüler]] was his sister-in-law. [[Edward Lasker]], born in Kempen (Kępno), [[Greater Poland]] (then [[Prussia]]), the German-American [[International Master|chess master]], engineer, and author, claimed that he was distantly related to Emanuel Lasker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geocities.com/siliconvalley/lab/7378/relative.htm |accessdate=2008-11-21 |title=Relatives of Chessplayers |publisher=GeoCities.com |author=Bill Wall |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091028033711/http://www.geocities.com/siliconvalley/lab/7378/relative.htm |archivedate=October 28, 2009 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref> They both played in the great [[New York 1924 chess tournament]].<ref>{{cite magazine
 | last=Lasker
 | first=Edward
 | date=March 1974
 | title=The New York Tournament of 1924
 | magazine=Chess Life & Review
 | quote=I did not discover that we were actually related until he told me shortly before his death that someone had shown him a Lasker family tree on one of whose branches I was dangling
}}</ref>

 | website=[[Chessgames.com]]
}}</ref> Although this was not the earliest-known game with a successful two-bishops [[sacrifice (chess)|sacrifice]], this combination is now known as a "Lasker–Bauer combination" or "Lasker sacrifice".<ref name="JeffreysReviewWhyLaskerMatters"/>
*Harry Nelson Pillsbury vs. Emanuel Lasker, St Petersburg 1895.<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1109097
 | title=Harry Nelson Pillsbury vs. Emanuel Lasker, St Petersburg 1895
 | website=[[Chessgames.com]]
}}</ref> A brilliant sacrifice on the 17th move leads to a victorious attack.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker" />
*Wilhelm Steinitz vs. Emanuel Lasker, London 1899.<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1132758
 | title=Wilhelm Steinitz vs. Emanuel Lasker, London 1899
 | website=[[Chessgames.com]]
}}</ref> The old champion and the new one really go for it.<ref>{{cite book
| title=500 Master Games of Chess |author1=Tartakower, S.G.  |author2=Du Mont, J. | publisher=Courier Dover Publications | year=1975 | isbn=0-486-23208-5 | page=270 (game number 209)
| url=https://books.google.com/?id=yfe7qbmvqkkC&pg=RA1-PA269&dq=steinitz+lasker#PRA1-PA270,M1 | accessdate=2008-12-29
}}</ref>
*Frank James Marshall vs. Emanuel Lasker, World Championship Match 1907, game 1.<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1094674
 | title=Frank James Marshall vs. Emanuel Lasker, World Championship Match 1907, game 1
 | website=[[Chessgames.com]]
}}</ref> Lasker's attack is insufficient for a quick win, so he trades it in for an [[chess endgame|endgame]] in which he quickly ties Marshall in knots.<ref>{{cite book
| title=Chess Fundamentals | author=Capablanca, J.R. | chapter=Example 30 | isbn=1-85744-073-0 | edition=Algebraic, 1994
| url=https://archive.org/stream/chessfundamental00capa/chessfundamental00capa_djvu.txt | accessdate=2008-12-29
| year=1994
| publisher=Everyman Chess
| location=London
}} A key position is discussed at {{cite web
| url=http://chessforallages.blogspot.com/2006/12/endgame-marshall-lasker-1907-match-game.html | accessdate=2008-12-29
| title=Endgame: Marshall - Lasker, 1907 Match, Game 1 | author=Mark Weeks
}}</ref>
*Emanuel Lasker vs. Carl Schlechter, match 1910, game 10.<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1121156
 | title=Emanuel Lasker vs. Carl Schlechter, match 1910, game 10
 | website=[[Chessgames.com]]
}}</ref> Not a great game, but the one that saved Lasker from losing his world title in 1910.<ref name="Pachman1987DecisiveGamesWCh1910">{{cite book
| title=Decisive Games in Chess History | author=Pachman, L.
| publisher=Courier Dover Publications | year=1987 | isbn=0-486-25323-6
| pages=48–51 | chapter=11: World Championship Match 1910
| url=https://books.google.com/?id=jlgJTCyonAgC&pg=PA48&dq=lasker+schlechter+1910 | accessdate=2008-12-29 | others=Russell, A.S.
}}</ref>
*Emanuel Lasker vs. Jose Raul Capablanca, St Petersburg 1914.<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1258181
 | title=Emanuel Lasker vs. Jose Raul Capablanca, St Petersburg 1914
 | website=[[Chessgames.com]]
}}</ref> Lasker, who needed a win here, surprisingly used a {{chessgloss|quiet}} opening, allowing Capablanca to {{chessgloss|simplify}} the game early. There has been much debate about whether Lasker's approach represented subtle psychology or deep positional understanding.<ref name="Fine1952WorldsGreatChessGamesEmLasker" /><ref name="KramnikSteinitzToKasparov" /><ref name="Pachman1987StPetersburg1914" />
*Max Euwe vs. Emanuel Lasker, Zurich 1934.<ref>{{cite web
 | url=http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1008008
 | title=Max Euwe vs. Emanuel Lasker, Zurich 1934
 | website=[[Chessgames.com]]
}}</ref> 66-year-old Lasker beats a future World Champion, sacrificing his queen to turn defence into attack.<ref>{{cite book
| title=How to Defend in Chess: Learn from the World Champions | author=Crouch, C.
| publisher=Gambit Publications | year=2007 | isbn=1-904600-83-2 | chapter=Game 9
| url=http://www.jeremysilman.com/book_reviews_jw/jw_ht_defend_chess.html | accessdate=2008-12-29
}}</ref>

[[City University of New York]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Joseph Fels Ritt]] | doctoral_students = | known_for = [[Levi's reduction process]] }} '''Howard Levi''' (November 9, 1916 in [[New York City]] – September 11, 2002 in New York City) was an American [[mathematician]] who worked mainly in [[algebra]] and [[Mathematics education|mathematical education]].[http://www.ams.org/notices/200306/inside.pdf ''Notices of the AMS'', June/July 2003, Volume 50, Number 6, p. 705.] Levi was very active during the educational reforms in the United States, having proposed several new courses to replace the traditional ones. ==Biography== Levi earned a Ph.D. in mathematics from [[Columbia University]] in 1942 as a student of [[Joseph Fels Ritt]].{{MathGenealogy|id=37383}} Soon after obtaining his degree, he became a researcher on the [[Manhattan Project]].[[Melvin Fitting]] – [http://comet.lehman.cuny.edu/fitting/fourcolor/fourcolor.html The Four Color Theorem]For some details, consult: Mildred Goldberg – [http://www.gilderlehrman.org/collections/c66c2257-6a12-48d4-b345-482222175359 Personal recollections of Mildred Goldberg, secretary to the theoretical group, SAM Laboratories, The Manhattan Project; 1943-1946] ([[Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History]]). At [[Wesleyan University]] he led a group that developed a course of geometry for high school students that treated [[Euclidean geometry]] as a special case of [[affine geometry]].{{cite book|author-first=Nathalie|author-last=Sinclair|authorlink=Nathalie Sinclair|title=The History of the Geometry Curriculum in the United States|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K7U6I3fxRSoC&pg=PA64|year=2008|publisher=IAP|isbn=978-1-59311-697-2|pages=64}}Sitomer, H. – Coordinate geometry with an affine approach, Mathematics Teacher 57 (1964), 404–405. Much of the Wesleyan material was based on his book ''Foundations of Geometry and Trigonometry''.C. Ray Wylie, [http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED085260.pdf An Affine Approach to Euclidean Geometry (p. 237 from the PDF document, p. 231 from the document itself)] His book ''Polynomials, Power Series, and Calculus'', written to be a textbook for a first course in [[calculus]],[https://www.jstor.org/stable/2312681 Levi, Howard — An Experimental Course in Analysis for College Freshmen] presented an innovative approach, and received favorable reviews by [[Leonard Gillman]], who wrote "[...] this book, with its wealth of imaginative ideas, deserves to be better known."{{cite journal|author= Gillman, Leonard|authorlink=Leonard Gillman|title=An Axiomatic Approach to the Integral|journal=The American Mathematical Monthly|year=1993|volume=100|issue=1|pages=16–25|url=https://www.maa.org/sites/default/files/pdf/upload_library/22/Ford/Gillman16-25.pdf|doi=10.2307/2324809|jstor=2324809}}{{cite journal|author= Gillman, Leonard|authorlink=Leonard Gillman|title=Review: ''Polynomials, Power Series, and Calculus'' by Howard Levi|journal=The American Mathematical Monthly|year=1974|volume=81|issue=5|pages=532–533|jstor=2318616|doi=10.2307/2318616}} [[Levi's reduction process]] is named after him.{{cite journal|author=Mead, D. G.|title=The Equation of Ramanujan-Nagell and [y2]|journal=Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society|date=December 1973|volume=41|issue=2|pages=333–341|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/proc/1973-041-02/S0002-9939-1973-0327725-4/S0002-9939-1973-0327725-4.pdf|doi=10.2307/2039090|jstor=2039090}} In his last years, he tried to find a proof of the [[four color theorem]] that did not rely on computers. == Selected publications == === Books === * ''Elements of Algebra'' (Chelsea Publishing Company, 1953, 1956, 1960, 1961){{cite journal|author= Halmos, Paul R.|authorlink=Paul Halmos|title=Review: ''Elements of algebra'' by Howard Levi|journal=Bull. pages.title: Jean-Louis Loday
pages.text:
'''Jean-Louis Loday''' (12 January 1946 – 6 June 2012) was a French mathematician who worked on [[cyclic homology]] and who introduced [[Leibniz algebra]]s (sometimes called Loday algebras) and [[Zinbiel algebra]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euro-math-soc.eu/node/2779 |title=Jean-Louis Loday 1946-2012 | The European Mathematical Society |publisher=Euro-math-soc.eu |date=2012-06-08 |accessdate=2012-06-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130213062654/http://www.euro-math-soc.eu/node/2779 |archivedate=2013-02-13 |df= }}</ref>
He occasionally used the pseudonym '''Guillaume William Zinbiel''', formed by reversing the last name of [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz]].

Loday studied at [[Lycée Louis-le-Grand]] and at [[École Normale Supérieure]] in [[Paris]].  He completed his [[Ph.D.]] at the [[University of Strasbourg]] in 1975 under the supervision of [[Max Karoubi]], with a dissertation titled ''K-Théorie algébrique et représentations de groupes''. He went on to become a senior scientist at [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique|CNRS]] and a member of the Institute for Advanced Mathematical Research (IRMA) at the University of Strasbourg.

[[National Medal of Science]] (1989) |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Saunders Mac Lane''' (4 August 1909 – 14 April 2005) was an [[United States|American]] [[mathematician]] who co-founded [[category theory]] with [[Samuel Eilenberg]]. ==Early life and education== Mac Lane was born in [[Norwich, Connecticut]], near where his family lived in [[Taftville, Connecticut|Taftville]].{{citation|contribution=Saunders Mac Lane|title=More Mathematical People|editor1-first=Donald J.|editor1-last=Albers|editor2-first=Gerald L.|editor2-last=Alexanderson|editor2-link=Gerald L. Alexanderson|editor3-first=Constance|editor3-last=Reid|editor3-link=Constance Reid|publisher=Harcourt Brace Jovanovich|year=1990|pages=196–219}}. He was christened "Leslie Saunders MacLane", but "Leslie" fell into disuse because his parents, Donald MacLane and Winifred Saunders, came to dislike it. He began inserting a space into his surname because his first wife found it difficult to type the name without a space.Mac Lane (2005), p. 6. He was the oldest of three brothers; one of his brothers, Gerald MacLane, also became a mathematics professor at [[Rice University]] and [[Purdue University]]. Another sister died as a baby. His father and grandfather were both ministers; his grandfather had been a [[Presbyterian]], but was kicked out of the church for believing in [[evolution]], and his father was a [[Congregational church|Congregationalist]]. His mother, née Winifred Saunders, studied at [[Mount Holyoke College]] and taught English, Latin, and mathematics. In high school, Mac Lane's favorite subject was [[chemistry]]. While in high school, his father died, and he came under his grandfather's care. His half-uncle, a lawyer, was determined to send him to [[Yale University]], where many of his relatives had been educated, and paid his way there beginning in 1926. As a freshman, he became disillusioned with chemistry. His mathematics instructor, [[Lester S. Hill]], coached him for a local mathematics competition which he won, setting the direction for his future work. He went on to study mathematics and physics as a double major, taking courses from [[Jesse Beams]], [[Ernest William Brown]], [[Ernest Lawrence]], [[F. S. C. Northrop]], and [[Øystein Ore]], among others. He graduated from Yale with a B.A. in 1930. During this period, he published his first scientific paper, in [[physics]] and co-authored with [[Irving Langmuir]]. In 1929, at a party of Yale football supporters in [[Montclair, New Jersey]], Mac Lane (there to be presented with a prize for having the best grade point average yet recorded at Yale) had met [[Robert Maynard Hutchins]], the new president of the [[University of Chicago]], who encouraged him to go there for his graduate studies and soon afterwards offered him a scholarship. Mac Lane neglected to actually apply to the program, but showed up and was admitted anyway. At Chicago, the subjects he studied included [[set theory]] with [[E. H. Moore]], [[number theory]] with [[Leonard Eugene Dickson]], the [[calculus of variations]] with [[Gilbert Ames Bliss]], and logic with [[Mortimer J. Adler]]. In 1931, having earned his master's degree and feeling restless at Chicago, he earned a fellowship from the Institute of International Education and became one of the last Americans to study at the [[University of Göttingen]] prior to its decline under the Nazis. His greatest influences there were [[Paul Bernays]] and [[Hermann Weyl]]. By the time he finished his doctorate in 1934, Bernays had been forced to leave because he was Jewish, and Weyl became his main examiner. At Göttingen, Mac Lane also studied with [[Gustav Herglotz]] and [[Emmy Noether]]. Within days of finishing his degree, he married Dorothy Jones, from Chicago, and soon returned to the U.S.{{cite journal|author=Mac Lane, Saunders|title=Mathematics at Göttingen under the Nazis|journal=Notices of the AMS|date=Oct 1995|volume=42|issue=10|pages=1134–1138|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/199510/maclane.pdf}}{{cite journal|journal=Notices of the AMS|author=Segal, Sanford L.|authorlink=Sanford L. Segal|title=Letters to the Editor: Corrections on Mac Lane's Article|date=April 1996|volume=43|issue=4|pages=405–406|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/199604/letters.pdf}} ==Career== From 1934 through 1938, Mac Lane held short term appointments at [[Yale University]], [[Harvard University]], [[Cornell University]], and the [[University of Chicago]]. He then held a tenure track appointment at Harvard from 1938 to 1947. In 1941, while giving a series of visiting lectures at the [[University of Michigan]], he met [[Samuel Eilenberg]] and began what would become a fruitful collaboration on the interplay between algebra and topology. In 1944 and 1945, he also directed Columbia University's Applied Mathematics Group, which was involved in the war effort as a contractor for the [[Applied Mathematics Panel]]; the mathematics he worked on in this group concerned [[differential equation]]s for [[fire-control system]]s. In 1947, he accepted an offer to return to Chicago, where (in part because of the university's involvement in the [[Manhattan Project]], and in part because of the administrative efforts of [[Marshall Stone]]) many other famous mathematicians and physicists had also recently moved. He traveled as a [[Guggenheim Fellow]] to [[ETH Zurich]] for the 1947–1948 term, where he worked with [[Heinz Hopf]]. Mac Lane succeeded Stone as department chair in 1952, and served for six years. Mac Lane was vice president of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] and the [[American Philosophical Society]], and president of the [[American Mathematical Society]]. While presiding over the [[Mathematical Association of America]] in the 1950s, he initiated its activities aimed at improving the teaching of modern mathematics. He was a member of the [[National Science Board]], 1974–1980, advising the American government. In 1976, he led a delegation of mathematicians to [[China]] to study the conditions affecting mathematics there. Mac Lane was elected to the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] in 1949, and received the [[National Medal of Science]] in 1989. ==Contributions== After a thesis in [[mathematical logic]], his early work was in [[field theory (mathematics)|field theory]] and [[Valuation (algebra)|valuation theory]]. He wrote on [[valuation ring]]s and [[Witt vector]]s, and separability in infinite [[field extension]]s. He started writing on [[group extension]]s in 1942, and in 1943 began his research on what are now called [[Eilenberg–Mac Lane space|Eilenberg–MacLane space]]s K(''G'',''n''), having a single non-trivial [[homotopy group]] ''G'' in dimension ''n''. This work opened the way to [[group cohomology]] in general. After introducing, via the [[Eilenberg–Steenrod axioms]], the abstract approach to [[homology theory]], he and Eilenberg originated [[category theory]] in 1945. He is especially known for his work on [[coherence theorem]]s. A recurring feature of category theory, [[abstract algebra]], and of some other mathematics as well, is the use of [[commutative diagram|diagrams]], consisting of arrows ([[morphism]]s) linking objects, such as [[product (category theory)|products]] and [[coproduct]]s. According to McLarty (2005), this diagrammatic approach to contemporary mathematics largely stems from Mac Lane (1948). Mac Lane also coined the term [[Yoneda lemma]] for a lemma which is an essential background to many central concepts of category theory and which was discovered by [[Nobuo Yoneda]].{{cite web|title=Prof. Nobuo Yoneda passed away|last=Kinoshita|first=Yoshiki|url=http://www.mta.ca/~cat-dist/catlist/1999/yoneda|accessdate=21 December 2013|date=23 April 1996}} Mac Lane had an exemplary devotion to writing approachable texts, starting with his very influential ''A Survey of Modern Algebra'', coauthored in 1941 with [[Garrett Birkhoff]]. From then on, it was possible to teach elementary modern algebra to undergraduates using an English text. His ''[[Categories for the Working Mathematician]]'' remains the definitive introduction to category theory. Mac Lane supervised the Ph.Ds of, among many others, [[David Eisenbud]], [[William Alvin Howard|William Howard]], [[Irving Kaplansky]], [[Michael D. Morley|Michael Morley]], [[Anil Nerode]], [[Robert Solovay]], and [[John G. Thompson]]. In addition to reviewing a fair amount of his mathematical output, the obituary articles McLarty (2005, 2007) clarify Mac Lane's contributions to the [[philosophy of mathematics]]. Mac Lane (1986) is an approachable introduction to his views on this subject. ==Selected works== * 1997 (1941). ''A Survey of Modern Algebra'' (with [[Garrett Birkhoff]]). Chelsea. {{isbn|0-8218-1646-2}} * 1998 (1972). ''[[Categories for the Working Mathematician]]'', Springer ([[Graduate Texts in Mathematics]]) {{isbn|0-387-98403-8}} * 1986. pages.title: Cyrus Colton MacDuffee
pages.text:
'''Cyrus Colton MacDuffee''' (June 29, 1895 – August 21, 1961) from [[Oneida, New York]] was a professor of mathematics at [[University of Wisconsin]].
He wrote a number of influential research papers in [[abstract algebra]]. MacDuffee served on the Council of the [[American Mathematical Society]] (A.M.S.), was editor of the ''[[Transactions of the American Mathematical Society|Transactions of the A.M.S.]]'', and served as president of the [[Mathematical Association of America]] (M.A.A).<ref name="maa">[http://www.maa.org/history/presidents/macduffee.html MAA presidents: Cyrus Colton MacDuffee]</ref><ref name="osu">[https://web.archive.org/web/20120729121107/http://www.math.osu.edu/history/biographies/CyrusMacDuffee.html Biography from Ohio State University]</ref><ref name="mactutor">{{MacTutor|id=MacDuffee}}</ref>

MacDuffee obtained his B.S. degree in 1917 from [[Colgate University]] and a Ph.D. in 1922 from the [[University of Chicago]] ; his thesis was on [[Nonassociative algebra]]s under the direction of [[Leonard E. Dickson]]. In 1935, MacDuffee joined the University of Wisconsin, where he remained until his death in 1961. He served as chair of the department(1951–56). Later, Wisconsin endowed a university chair under his name. Prior to joining the University of Wisconsin, he served at [[Princeton University|Princeton]] and [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]].<ref name="maa"/><ref name="osu"/><ref name="mactutor"/> He guided 30 Ph.D. students, among them [[D. R. Fulkerson]], [[H. J. Ryser]], and [[Bonnie Stewart]].<ref>{{mathgenealogy|id=6071}}</ref>
